instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.C6905: What is C6905? Capacitor to ground on charger input, if this shorts to ground the charger will not put out any power. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
Hi, have this Touch Bar Board here I'm having trouble diagnosing. It pulls a steady 0.015A at 5.2V but never jumps to 20V. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is missing, but the Enable on Pin 10 of <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> is present at 5.4V. Anyone know how to proceed? This is one of my first TouchBars I'm working on so I'm not that experienced with them at all...

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
Missing <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, board will never start.

Check diode mode at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> first.
If no short (nor low value), post <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
Diode Mode on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> measured at <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> is .397 and Voltages at <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> are:


Pin 1 - 0V
Pin 2 - 0V
Pin 3 - 0V
Pin 4 - 0V
Pin 5 - 0V
Pin 7 - 0V
Pin 8 - 0V
Pin 9 - 0V
Pin 10 - 0V

It in fact doesn?t have the enable on Pin 10. I think I confused <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> with <RESISTOR>R6921</RESISTOR>. Sorry! Mistakes sometimes happen though...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message: Do you get any voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
Pin 1 - 5.1V
Pin 2 - 5.1V
Pin 3 - 0V
Pin 4 - 5.1V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
All pins MUST have the same voltage.
Do you really have 0V at <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR>???

Check <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> and <DIODE>D6902</DIODE>.
Post diode mode to ground at <CAPACITOR>C6905</CAPACITOR>/06.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
Correction: Its 5.1V. Don't know what I did there... 

At <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> its 5.3V at <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> its 5.3V at Pin 1 and 3, Pin 2 (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_R</SIGNAL>) is 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
"Pin 2 - 0V
------------------------------
5.3V at Pin 1"
Another mistake???
Or broken trace...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
No, really 0V! 

Diode mode is:

At <CAPACITOR>C6905</CAPACITOR> - .54
At <CAPACITOR>C6906</CAPACITOR> - .53

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
Mentioned points are in the same power rail.
So, broken trace???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message: So <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR_R</SIGNAL> (Pin 1) = <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_R</SIGNAL> (Pin 2)?

threads.message: This one is confusing me

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:

"Voltages at <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> are:
Pin 2 - 0V
----------------------
<DIODE>D6902</DIODE> its 5.3V at Pin 1 and 3"

"Pin 2 - 0V
------------------------------
5.3V at Pin 1 and 3"

Sorry for confusion; I forgot to mention pin 3/<DIODE>D6902</DIODE> before...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
Remeasured everything....


<DIODE>D6902</DIODE>:
Pin 1 - 5.4V
Pin 2 - 0V
Pin 3 - 5.3V

Very interesting, the board briefly went to 20V at .161A for 60sec before going back down to 5. But now its no longer drawing .020A but 0.15A...

While it was at 20V I got these readings:
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:
Pin 1 - 0V
Pin 2 - 5.2V
Pin 3 - 3.5V
Pin 4 - 0V
Pin 5 - 0V
Pin 7 - 0V
Pin 8 - 5V
Pin 9 - 1V
Pin 10 - 2.78V


Also I noticed these reads vary a lot depending on which port I use that's why my readings are so inconsistent 


I found out: 

1st Port - 5V@0.005A - Initially also 0.155 with a warm <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> but after letting it sit it went to this
2nd Port - 5V@0.155A and a warm <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip
3rd Port - 5V@0.155A and a warm <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip
4th Port - 5V@0.020A 


Also the Voltage on <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> and <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> vary depending on the port. Should I post the voltages for <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> and <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> for every one of the 4 ports?

Any idea what could be causing this big mess?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
Different behaviour on USB-C ports indicates that one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip is damaged; the most probably reason.
Compare diode mode readings, on their LDO outputs, between all them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message: Which LDO Line?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
There are 3 types of LDO outputs; check all them.
Use external names for these lines, not the ones inside chip marking...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message:
Finally got around around to measuring this:

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>LDO_3V3</SIGNAL> - .006
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8A</SIGNAL> - .526
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8D</SIGNAL> - .027
<SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - .51

UB300
<SIGNAL>LDO_3V3</SIGNAL> - .007
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8A</SIGNAL> - .522
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8D</SIGNAL> - .006
<SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - .521

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>LDO_3V3</SIGNAL> - .433
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8A</SIGNAL> - .528
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8D</SIGNAL> - .493
<SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - .522

UB400
<SIGNAL>LDO_3V3</SIGNAL> - .446
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8A</SIGNAL> - .538
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8D</SIGNAL> - .507
<SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - .524


Hope these help!

threads.message: <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and UB300 are both suspects...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message: Should I just get 2 replacement chips and replace both?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 15" TouchBar pulling 5V@0.015A
threads.message: Yes, because you have 2 rails (no common point) shorted to ground.
